Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: The Effect of Interspecific Hybridization on MHC Diversity in Wild Baboons

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the 'arms race' against pathogens, having less common immune genes can be advantageous. Infectious agents may have evolved to evade the defenses of the more common varieties, making organisms with rare variants more likely to survive. In primates, like all vertebrates, many proteins essential to the immune system are encoded by the Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC), which is involved in resistance to pathogens such as HIV and tuberculosis. The advantage of having rare forms has made the MHC gene complex one of the most diverse regions in the human genome. Recently, researchers found that at least one variant of the MHC entered the human gene pool when the ancestors of some modern humans interbred with an extinct hominin. The novel form's rarity may have facilitated the introduction and spread of the MHC variant through the population.

To better understand the effects of hybridization on MHC, this research by doctoral student Christina Bergey (New York University), under the guidance of Dr. Todd Disotell, focuses on a natural experiment in which two species of baboons successfully interbreed in Ethiopia. Using the latest DNA sequencing techniques, MHC loci are genetically typed and thousands of neutral markers from individuals across the hybrid zone are utilized to test whether MHC alleles are able to transfer and spread widely throughout the parental population. The Ethiopian baboon hybrid zone offers an ideal opportunity to explore the influence of selection and hybridization on MHC diversity in an appropriate primate model.

The study increases our understanding of hybridization, a phenomenon that has affected our lineage numerous times. It also provides evolutionary context to primate MHC variation, which has behavioral, immunological, and biomedical importance. DNA sequences are deposited in publicly available databases and all software is made freely available online and released under open source licenses. Since increasing public understanding of evolution is an essential goal of anthropological research, new forms of outreach to publicize the results also are employed in the conduct of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project have been to characterize the nature of the hybrid zone found between two species of baboons (genus Papio) in Ethiopia and to test whether specific portions of the genome are preferentially introgressing across the species boundary and whether regions that differ markedly between the species may underlie their specific traits. To do this, I have sequenced hundreds of individuals at thousands of locations spread randomly throughout the genome using the latest genomic techniques. I have also genotyped the animals at locations within the MHC, a collection of immune genes. Using these datasets, I have been able to describe the genetic structure of the hybrid zone and find regions of the genome that differ from the background which could be candidates for adaptive introgression or associated with reproductive isolation.


Over 220 individual baboons from the hybrid zone were sequenced at thousands of locations genome-wide, making this the largest population genomic study of a wild primate hybrid zone to date. These thousands of variants spread throughout the genome provide a view of the population structure of the hybrid zone at a higher resolution than ever before possible, and the variants discovered with be of use to future research on the two species. Additionally, the dataset has allowed the identification of regions of the genome that show outlier patterns of differentiation or introgression, and which thus warrant further study for possible connections to adaptive introgression or reproductive isolation


Significant results of the project include the finding that the position of the hybrid zone remains stable despite the presence of migrants in groups with "mismatched" ancestry, suggesting that purer animals may be choosing not to mate with hybrids, which could potentially limit hybridization. Nonetheless, the distribution of inferred ancestry estimates suggest that the hybrid zone has been present for much time, with breeding between members of the parent species and hybrids and interbreeding among the hybrids.


Regions of the genome and various functional categories were identified as outliers for differentiation between the parental species or gene flow among the hybrids. Some such functional categories are biomedically important, such as pathways related to neurotransmitters that are known to influence behavior in humans and other animals. For instance, the dopamine mediated signalling pathway was enriched for regions of high differentiation between the parental species. Various pathways related to serotonin were found to be outliers for biased introgression among the hybrids. The present study has identified such pathways, which may influence behavior and thus determine the likelihood of interbreeding between species, as worthy of further study to better understand the evolutionary impact of hybridization. Additionally, they are of interest for their connection to various human disorders, such as Parkinson's Disease. More information on these pathways in wild primates is useful since baboons are often used as model organisms for the study of such diseases.


The results of the study have been presented at academic conferences and talks, and several publications are in preparation. The work on the project, both laboratory and computational, resulted in the training of several female undergraduates some of whom have decided to pursue a degree in genomics or a related field. The computational pipeline will be made freely available and published under an open source license and has been utilized by several other researchers applying the same technique to various species of primates.
